'''Note:''' Edited version for easier reading (includes spelling corrections etc.)

==== Will canonical raise the support for LoCos? ====
''By: jimbo at 16:10''

'''Mark:''' jimbo: are there specific things you have in mind?

'''jimbo:''' disc

'''Mark:''' I think we do quite a bit already, wrt hosting, cd's, events.  We looked at sending cd's to loco teams for redistribution, but it didn't work well in the end.  But we do respond to some requests, we can't send everything requested, it would cost millions and we would rather support more floss development.

==== What grand plans do you have for Ubuntu on the Mobile and embedded platform? ====
''By: hendrixski at 16:11''

'''Mark:''' That's a very exciting project
linux is going to be in every home, and office, in the form of consumer electronics.  It started with set-top boxes but now a lot of electronics are powerful enough to run Linux and soon, that will all go mobile so, not so much grand plans as providing a  reliable platform for people to build great products bring the best of ubuntu - free software, free license, standard platform with apt and security updates, to that community.

==== Why Debian (in a good sense)  instead of all the beautiful distros? What made you choose this one particularly? Is it the packaging capabilities/administration or the community that would most probably grow as the years go by? ====
''By: savvas at 16:14''

'''Mark:''' First, the philosophy of (a) license precision, (b) freedom, (c) quality that makes debian unique - it's a superb forum for building a shared, common platform and we want to be part of a broader community like that.  Second, because I have been a DD since 1996 :-)  Third, because of the breadth of packages our relationship with debian is very important, and we work hard at it sometimes I'm disappointed by individuals there, but in general i still think it's a good partnership and i think we give a lot back which people often don't measure but i think we contribute more to debian than any other organization, or derivative, so I feel good about it.

==== Hi Mark. I know UDS is some days ahead but do you already have a "plan" for Hardy in mind? Or will it just be a LTS-release? ====
''By: dee at 16:15''

'''Mark:'''  :-)

'''Mark:'''  The plan is only ever complete after UDS.  I know server and mobile will both get a lot of attention with folks from upstream, partners, customers etc all there to talk about them.  LTS is very important - it does influence how we run the release and plan features as for specifics - come to Boston next week!

==== What kinds of partnership opportunities with Canonical are available to entrepreneurs who want to start a business, and use Linux in their office and/or in their product (i.e. a phone or an appliance)? ====
''By:  hendrixski at 16:17''

'''Mark:''' We have a range of partner programs - training, engineering, oem, isv, ihv and others too.  Best person to speak with is Malcolm Yates - malcolm.yates@canonical.com

==== How do you guys measure the popularity of ubuntu? I mean what metrics are used? ====
''By: no_mind at 16:18''

'''Mark:''' We have some visibility on downloads, more than 1 million people came to ubuntu.com/download last week :-)  But remember, we have 300 mirrors, so that's only a limited view.  We don't have any registration or hidden monitoring.  But ubuntu machines, like any OS "look slightly different" on the net apache server tag lines, or browser lines and so ubuntu users leave a footprint, and we can measure growth pretty accurately.  Needless to say the community continues to grow at a phenomenal pace.

==== Hi Mark - Of major importance to the growth of Ubuntu and Linux in general is hardware compatibility.  Is the message getting across to the hardware manufacturers? ====
''By:  mzungu_ at 16:20''

'''Mark:''' Yes!

'''Mark:'''  Partly, announcements like Dell's and other OEM's help there.  People who provide them with components want to say "hey, our stuff works with Linux too!"  Also, the fact that consumer electronics (which have a lot of Linux work going on) and PC's are converging, helps if you make a bluetooth chip, you might as well sell that to a smartphone manufacturer, who could well have linux, as a laptop manufacturer, with windows that helps a lot.

17:10 <+sabdfl> thully: dan frye from IBM puts it best
17:11 <+sabdfl> he's referring to the linux kernel specifically
17:12 <+sabdfl> he says that "we have separated research and development, from productisation"
17:12 <+sabdfl> (sorry, RL conversation)
17:12 < brobostigon> hi
17:12 < r3m0t> bother that real life
17:12 <+sabdfl> what he means is that the linux kernel guys, at kernel.org and on the LKML, actually care ONLY about productisation
17:12 <+sabdfl> erk
17:12 <+sabdfl> about kernel core development
17:12 <+sabdfl> while the distros care ONLY about productisation
17:12 <+sabdfl> and that's PERFECT
17:13 < thully> so why a new distro?
17:13 <+sabdfl> in a normal software company, the SAME people have to be both good at R&D, during the early phase of the product cycle, and also good at integration / QA / documentation, at the end of the cycle
17:13 <+sabdfl> but with the linux kernel, we separate those two out perfectly
17:13 <+sabdfl> so, i know Debian very well indeed
17:14 <+sabdfl> and initially i thought we might be able to do Ubuntu inside Debian, but pushing hard to narrow its focus
17:14 <+sabdfl> and then i realised that this would be a huge mistake
17:14 <+sabdfl> because, to do Ubuntu, you would need to cut out many of the things that make Debian wonderful
17:14 <+sabdfl> effectively, Debian sid is like the LKML
17:14 <+sabdfl> and we are like a distro that produces a release kernel from their work
17:15 <+sabdfl> that's actually a very powerful structure
17:15 <+sabdfl> other people also do amazing but DIFFERENT things with the output from Debian
17:15 <+sabdfl> so, this is the better way
